IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 15177 S0926-860X(14)00800-X 10.1016/j.apcata.2014.12.038 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Correlation of M3+ ionic radius of the lanthanides with BET surface area of the promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 2 Synchrotron XRD patterns of samples before reduction (A=γ-Al2O3 or NiAl2O4). Fig. 3 Synchrotron XRD patterns of reduced catalysts (A=γ-Al2O3 or NiAl2O4). Fig. 4 Ni 2p XPS spectra of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, with un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 and NiO catalysts. Fig. 5 Al 2p XPS spectra of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3, un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 6 H2-TPR profiles of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, with un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 and NiO catalysts. Fig. 7 (A) Bright field TEM images and (B) Ni particle size distribution of reduced catalysts. Fig. 8 (A) CH4 and (B) CO2 conversions over Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts promoted with different lanthanide elements (after 2h in situ reduction). Fig. 9 Synchrotron X-ray diffraction patterns of spent catalysts (A=γ-Al2O3 or NiAl2O4). Fig. 10 TEM micrographs of spent Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 11 Correlation of I D/I G ratio of spent Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with (A) Ni particle size and (B) percentage of deactivation (POD %). Table 1 Textural and chemical characteristics of prepared Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Understanding the role of lanthanide promoters on the structure–activity of nanosized Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts in carbon dioxide reforming of methane Mohamad Hassan Amin a Sudarsanam Putla a S. Bee Abd Hamid b Suresh K. Bhargava a ⁎ a Centre for Advanced Materials & Industrial Chemistry, School of Applied Sciences, RMIT University, Melbourne, VIC 3001, Australia Centre for Advanced Materials & Industrial Chemistry, School of Applied Sciences, RMIT University Melbourne VIC 3001 Australia b Nanotechnology & Catalysis Research Centre (NANOCAT), University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur 50603, Malaysia Nanotechnology & Catalysis Research Centre (NANOCAT), University of Malaya Kuala Lumpur 50603 Malaysia ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +61 3 9925 3365; fax: +61 3 9925 3747. Graphical abstract The present work was undertaken to investigate the effect of different lanthanide promoters on the structure–activity properties of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for CO2 reforming of CH4. Accordingly, a number of lanthanides, namely Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Tm were incorporated into the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by means of sol–gel method. An extensive physicochemical characterisation was performed using XRD, TG-DTA, BET surface area, BJH, XPS, Raman, H2-TPR, and TEM techniques. Surprisingly, low initial conversions of CH4 and CO2 were obtained for promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts compared with un-promoted catalyst, which is due to the presence of smaller pore sizes in the promoted catalysts. The observed initial activity order for conversions of CH4 and CO2 is un-promoted >Eu>Tb>Ho>Tm>Er>Dy>Pr>Sm>Gd>Nd. Interestingly, promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited an outstanding efficiency in time-on-stream studies up to 60h than the un-promoted catalyst. This significant observation is mainly due to low amounts of amorphous coke deposited on the surface of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts compared with un-promoted catalyst. Among all investigated lanthanides, the Er-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed the best performance in CH4 conversion, which is attributed to optimum Ni particle size, more reducibility, and low amounts of amorphous coke formation. It was shown that the catalytic efficacy of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts is highly dependent on the nature of the promoter. These notable findings are expected to bring new opportunities in the design of novel promising catalytic materials for CO2 reforming of CH4. Keywords CO2 reforming of methane Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Lanthanide Promoter 1 Introduction Dry (CO2) reforming of methane (DRM) is one of the vital catalytic reactions due to its remarkable economic and environmental advantages. This process effectively converts both CO2 and methane (harmful greenhouse gases) into valuable syngas with a moderate H2/CO ratio. Syngas serves as a versatile building block for the production of many chemicals and fuels [1–3]. A major problem in DRM reaction is the necessity of high operating temperatures due to its high endothermicity nature (ΔH°298 =247kJmol−1). It is a well-known fact that the application of elevated temperature conditions leads to sintering of the active phase and thereby, rapid catalyst deactivation. In parallel to DRM reaction, several other side reactions also take place, such as reverse water–gas-shift reaction (H2O+CO→H2 +CO2), Boudouard reaction (2CO→CO2 +C), methane decomposition, and carbon disproportionation [4]. These reactions favour the coke formation on the catalyst surface, another key problem that drastically decreases the catalyst efficiency in DRM reaction. The development of promising catalysts with strong coke-resistance ability is therefore an issue of on-going investigations in dry reforming of methane. Ni supported on γ-Al2O3 (Ni/γ-Al2O3) is one of the well-studied catalytic systems for DRM reaction due to its high abundance of materials and reasonable catalytic activity. Unfortunately, the efficiency of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst readily decreases under reaction conditions due to sintering of Ni and large amounts of coke deposition on the catalyst surface. High dispersion of Ni is essential to inhibit coke formation. It is a well-established fact that reducing the particle size to nanoscale range results in improved metal dispersion. In addition, nanoparticles provide more steps/kinks on the catalyst surface, which play a favourable role in DRM reaction [5,6]. Several modification strategies have been reported to improve the structure–activity properties of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, including the method of catalyst preparation, the pre-treatment conditions, the incorporation of promoters, etc. Particularly, the addition of promoters to Ni/Al2O3 catalyst leads to a number of beneficial properties, such as high metal dispersion, larger BET surface area, and superior reducible nature, thus improved efficacy of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for DRM reaction. A wide variety of promoters have been incorporated into the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, such as alkali metals [7], alkaline earth metals [8], transition metals [9–12] and rare earth metals (lanthanides) [1,7,13–22]. Among all investigated promoters, lanthanides are potential candidates for enhancing the efficiency of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the DRM reaction [19,23–26]. The positive effects of lanthanides on structure–activity properties of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are (1) high dispersion of Ni on the surface of support [1,17,18,21,22,28–31], (2) inhibition of formation of NiAl2O4 phase [1,14,15,27], (3) formation of graphitised carbon rather than amorphous carbon [1,7,32,33], (4) promotion of CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface [34], and (5) enhanced chemical environment of Ni at the Ni–lanthanide interface [35,36]. Till now, most of the studies have been focused on understanding the effect of a few lanthanide promoters on efficacy of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the DRM reaction. However, investigating the role of a wide variety of lanthanides on structure–activity properties of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is vital to design novel promising catalysts for sustainable DRM process. The present work was undertaken against the above background. In this study, a number of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts promoted by Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Tm were synthesised by a sol–gel method. The efficiency of prepared catalysts was studied for DRM reaction using a fixed-bed quartz microreactor at atmospheric pressure. The structural and redox properties of the catalysts were thoroughly analysed with the help of synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), BET surface area, Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) analysis, thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, and H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) techniques. Significant efforts have been made to correlate the activity results with the physicochemical properties of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts promoted with various lanthanides, namely Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Tm were synthesised using a sol–gel method as reported previously [1]. The optimised composition of Ni and lanthanide promoters on Al2O3 support are 15 and 2%, respectively [1,37,38]. For comparison purpose, the un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was also synthesised using the same synthesis procedure. For convenience, the un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 and promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are referred to as pure and corresponding promoters, respectively, throughout the manuscript. Materials were also subjected to a reduction process to simulate that used in the activation of Ni based catalysts prior to use in catalytic CO2 reforming, which are henceforward referred to as reduced catalysts. This process involved exposing catalysts to a mixed flow of helium and H2 (40:10mLmin−1) for 2h at 700°C. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations XRD studies were performed on the synchrotron X-ray diffraction instrument using a Mythen microstrip detector and photon energy of 17.03keV (0.72888Å). The BET surface areas of the samples were determined by N2 adsorption–desorption measurements on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument at 77K. Prior to analysis, the sample was degassed under vacuum for 30min at ambient temperature followed by fast-mode degassing at 280°C for 12h. The elemental analysis of the catalysts was carried out with the help of X-ray fluorescence Bruker S4 and the energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX) attached to JEOL 2010 TEM operating at 200kV. TEM studies were made on a JEM-2100F instrument equipped with a slow-scan CCD camera and an accelerating voltage of the electron beam 200kV. The preparation of samples involves sonication in ethanol for 2–5min, followed by deposition of a drop on the copper grid supporting a perforated carbon film. H2-TPR measurements were carried out using a quartz reactor (I.D. 4.5mm), packed with 50mg catalyst in a flow (20mLmin−1) of H2–Ar mixture (4.14mol% H2) from 135 to 970°C at a linear heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The consumption of H2 was measured quantitatively by means of a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to TPR analysis, the catalysts were pre-treated at 500°C for 1h under the flow (20cm3 min−1) of argon. XPS studies were conducted on a Thermo K-5 Alpha XPS instrument using Al Kα (E =1486.6eV) radiation at a pressure lower than 10−9 torr to avoid noise in the spectra. The core level binding energies (BEs) were charge corrected with respect to the carbon (C 1s) peak at 285.0eV arising from the hydrocarbons adsorbed from the residual gas onto the catalysts. Raman experiments were performed on Perkin Elmer-Raman Station 400F spectrometer equipped with a liquid N2 cooled charge coupled device detector and a confocal microscope. 350mW near infrared 785nm laser was used for analysis. TG-DTA analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer TGA-7 instrument. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The efficacy of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and un-promoted catalyst for CO2 reforming of CH4 was studied using a fixed-bed continuous flow quartz reactor at atmospheric pressure and using a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 52,000mLg−1 h−1. Prior to analysis, the catalyst was reduced in situ in a mixed flow of H2 and He (10:40mLmin−1) at 700°C for 2h. The reactant gases (CO2 and CH4) were then fed (CO2:CH4:He=1:1:2mLmin−1) into the reactor. The product gas mixture was analysed by on-line gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC, 17A) equipped with a silica packed column and a TCD. The time-on-stream studies were carried out for all promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, with un-promoted catalyst at 700°C for 60h reaction time. The test conditions used in this study (feed flow rate, catalyst particle size, catalyst mass) have previously been shown to not lead to any internal or external mass transfer limitations [1]. 3 Results and discussion The investigated elemental analysis indicated that almost expected composition of the Ni at around 20% and lanthanides at around 2% was found for all catalysts as the synthesis method did not had any step where partial loss of metal could appear. The physiochemical properties of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, along with pure Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are presented in Table 1 . As can be seen from Table 1, the addition of promoters to Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst noticeably enhances its BET surface area. A correlation between the BET surface area of the catalysts and the ionic radius of lanthanides [39] was noticed in the present study (Fig. 1 ). Highest BET surface area was found for the Eu-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (167m2 g−1). On the other hand, the pore size of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was considerably decreased after the addition of lanthanide promoters. For example, the pore size values of Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Eu-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were found to be 8.17 and 7.68nm, respectively. Similar results were also found in the ytterbium and cerium promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts [1,14,40]. Surprisingly, no significant variation in the pore volume of Ni/γ-Al2O3 was found after the addition of lanthanides (Table 1). The XRD patterns of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and pure γ-Al2O3 are presented in Fig. 2 . It was found that all samples exhibit three major peaks at d values of 1.41, 2, and 2.41Å, indicating the presence of NiAl2O4 (and/or Al2O3) [14]. On the other hand, very weak XRD peaks were observed at d values of 1.49 and 2.09Å, which suggest the presence of NiO in the synthesised catalysts. Interestingly, the intensity of XRD patterns related to NiO phase is quite high in promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts compared with un-promoted catalyst. No XRD peaks corresponding to promoters were found in the present study, which is due to low loading of lanthanides in the present study. The XRD patterns of reduced catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 3 . The observed d values at 2.03, 1.79, 1.24, and 1.06Å can be assigned to (111), (200), (220) and (311) planes of cubic Ni0, respectively [14]. On the other hand, the intensities of XRD patterns related to NiAl2O4 (and/or Al2O3) are considerably varied after the reduction process. For the reduced catalysts also, XRD patterns related to lanthanide promoters were not found. The Ni 2p and Al 2p XPS spectra of the prepared catalysts are shown in Figs. 4 and 5 , respectively and the corresponding BEs, along with O 1s BEs of the catalysts (Fig. S1) are summarised in Table 2 . Appearance of Al 2p and Ni 2p3/2 peaks at 74.38 and 856.68eV, respectively, along with a satellite peak at 862.48eV indicate the formation of NiAl2O4 phase in the un-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst [14,41]. Interestingly, the binding energy of Ni 2p3/2 is significantly decreased for promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. This remarkable observation suggests the existence of strong interactions between Ni and lanthanide promotes, which inhibit the formation of NiAl2O4 phase in promoted catalysts. The origin of satellite peak (862.48eV) is mainly due to d8 →d8* transition or exchanged interactions of 2p and 3d electrons [42]. The presence of O 1s peak at 531.2eV also reveals the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel structure in the pure Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. S1) [41]. In contrast, the introduction of lanthanides strongly affects the surrounding chemical environment of Al and O in the promoted catalysts as evidenced by considerable shifting of Al 2p and O 1s peaks compared with the un-promoted catalyst (Table 2). This notable observation suggests that the addition of promoters to Ni/Al2O3 catalyst led to formation of separate Ni and γ-Al2O3 phases, which could play a key role in the dry reforming of methane as discussed in Section 2.3. Deconvolution of the Ni 2p spectra of reduced catalysts was performed by Gaussian–Lorentzian curve-fitting to determine the peak areas and to obtain relative surface concentrations of nickel species. The ratio of peak areas Ni0/(Ni0 +Ni2+) was used to illustrate the degree of reducibility [43]. As seen in Table 2, the addition of heavy and medium lanthanides led to an increase in the Ni0/(Ni0 +Ni2+) ratio, while the addition of light lanthanides results in decreased Ni0/(Ni0 +Ni2+) ratio in reduced Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. It is also interesting to note that the Ni0/(Ni0 +Ni2+) ratio on the surface of light lanthanides promoted catalysts has a very clear relationship with micropore volume of these materials (Table 1). This relation suggested that free Ni particles in these materials were being trapped inside micropores, resulting in the decrease of the fraction of free nickel particles on the surface of these catalysts, i.e., decreased Ni0/(Ni0 +Ni2+) ratio in the case of light lanthanides promoted catalysts. Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR profiles of pure NiO, un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 and promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. It was found that all catalysts exhibit two reduction peaks maxima in the range of ∼350–520 and 750–950°C. The presence of first peak indicates the reduction of NiO, while the appearance of second peak reveals the reduction of spinel type nickel–aluminium oxides [1,23,44–46]. The reducibility of Ni(II) in the synthesised catalysts was estimated on the basis of H2 consumption by assuming that the reducibility of pure NiO is 1 (Table 2). It was apparent from Table 2 that Er, Tb, Ho, Tm, and Eu promoters significantly improve the reducible nature of NiO, whereas quite opposite results were found for Pr-, Nd-, Sm-, Gd-, and Dy-promoted catalysts. Among, the Er-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst showed high H2 consumption at the first TPR peak, which could be the reason for its high catalytic efficacy in dry reforming of methane as discussed in the activity part. The particle size of Ni in reduced Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was estimated by means of TEM analysis. The crystallite and particle sizes of Ni in reduced Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were estimated by means of XRD (using Scherrer's equation) and TEM analysis, respectively and the results are presented in Table 2. As can be noted from Table 2, there was a good correlation in sizes particularly for particles smaller than 20nm, which showed that Ni particles do not have any significant sub grains, stacking fault, twins, or any such planar surface defects. It is clear from Table 2 that the addition of lanthanides, such as Eu, Tb, Ho, Er, and Tm reduce the Ni0 particle size, while larger sized Ni0 particles were found in the case of Pr-, Nd-, Sm-, Gd-, and Dy-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Especially, the Eu-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has smaller sized Ni particles (15.5nm), in line with the increase of BET surface area (Table 1). Fig. 7 shows bright field TEM images and the histograms in the Ni particle size distribution of reduced catalysts. As can be noted from Fig. 7, all samples exhibit nearly spherical shaped particles and fall in the nanoscale range with uniform size distribution. It can be seen from the histograms that the promoted catalysts had a more homogeneous particle size distribution than the un-promoted catalysts. The particle size distributions obtained show that the portion of largest particles is higher for un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3. The particle size distribution results observed for the lanthanide-promoted catalysts are consistent with results from previous studies that have shown that the addition of lanthanides including Yb [1], Pr [30], Ce [47] and La [48] can prevent transition metals from sintering and agglomerating. The efficiency of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, along with un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was studied for dry reforming of methane up to 60h reaction time and the obtained results in terms of CH4 and CO2 conversions were presented in Fig. 8(A) and (B), respectively. It was found that all catalysts show reasonable catalytic efficiency for dry reforming of methane. Surprisingly, the un-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst showed higher initial performance than the promoted catalysts. The observed initial activity order for both conversions of CH4 and CO2 is un-promoted >Eu>Tb>Ho>Tm>Er>Dy>Pr>Sm>Gd>Nd. It was found that the un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has high pore size compared with that of all promoted catalysts (Table 1), hence excellent initial performance of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in the DRM reaction (Fig. 8). It has been demonstrated that larger pores provide more accessible Ni active sites (high dispersion of active Ni sites inside the pore channels of support) for the reactants, resulting in higher catalytic activity [49,50]. As can be seen, in contrast to the performance of un-promoted catalyst which exhibited continuous deactivation during the reaction time, the conversions over the promoted catalysts were decreased during the initial reaction time and then tended to increase with time on stream, followed by a period of steady or a slight decreased activity. This can be attributed to the effect of several factors such as the amount and type of carbon species present on the surface of the catalysts, which affected the relation between the rate of carbon deposition and the rate of carbon removal. In the case of un-promoted catalyst, the rate of carbon deposition was higher than the rate of carbon removal, thus carbon started to accumulate on the Ni surface and cause the catalyst deactivation steadily during the time on stream [51]. As shown later, the reactive graphite and carbon nanotubes species were mainly observed on the promoted catalysts, which not only uncover the actives Ni sites and avoid the catalytic deactivation, but can also enhance Ni catalysed dry reforming of methane (as discussed in detail elsewhere [1,23,52–55]). In addition, the presence of lanthanide promoters may provide improved oxygen mobility of the catalyst resulting in the oxidation of carbonaceous species deposited on the active sites of the catalyst during the reaction, which promoted the mechanism of carbon removal from the Ni particles. Similar effect of oxygen mobility increases activity and stability due to the addition of lanthanide promoters, in line with the earlier reports [20–24,56,57]. These occurrences are altogether favourable for the slight increase in CH4 and CO2 conversions upon increasing the time of reaction for the lanthanide containing catalysts. It is therefore confirmed that despite the nature of lanthanides, all promoted catalysts exhibit superior durability in the dry reforming of methane up to 60h. The Er-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest efficiency: the achieved CH4 conversions for 0, 20, and 60h reaction times were 63.8, 66.8, and 67.2%, respectively. At thermodynamic equilibrium conditions (i.e., CH4/CO2 =1, atmospheric pressure and 700°C), methane and CO2 conversions would be approximately 79% and 85.5%, respectively [58]. In the present study, the reactions seems to be controlled by kinetics, thus the thermodynamic equilibrium conversions for the reactant were not achieved. The amount of coke deposited on spent catalysts after 20h reaction was estimated by TG-DTA analysis and the achieved results in terms of carbon deposition rate (CDR) are presented in Table 3 . It was found that all promoted catalysts exhibit low CDR values compared with that of un-promoted catalyst. This interesting observation indicates the favourable role of lanthanide promoters towards anti-coking ability of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst [46,59]. The XRD patterns of spent catalysts are presented in Fig. 9 . It was found that all catalysts show a characteristic broad peak at d value of 3.41Å, indicating the presence of amorphous carbon. In addition, two peaks were noticed at d values of 1.49 and 2.05Å, which reveal the existence of graphitised carbon (PDF card # 34-0567). A close examination of Fig. 9 reveals that more amorphous carbon was found in the un-promoted catalyst, whereas the proportion of graphitised carbon was high for the promoted catalysts. It has been demonstrated that amorphous carbon shows a negative effect on the long term activity of catalysts compared with graphitised carbon (or carbon nanotubes). It was shown that amorphous carbon limits the access of methane and carbon dioxide to the active nickel phase, thus decreased efficacy of un-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst under time-on-stream studies [60,61]. In contrast, carbon nanotubes may act as new active sites for the reforming reaction [1,8,23,52–55]. The types of carbon species deposited on the spent catalysts were investigated by means of TEM and Raman techniques. Fig. 10 shows the TEM images of the spent catalysts. Several types of carbon forms, such as carbon nanotubes and amorphous coke can be observed on the surface of spent catalysts. The proportion of deposited carbon as carbon nanotubes versus amorphous carbon was significantly higher for Er-, Sm-, and Tm-promoted catalysts. Raman spectroscopy was also used to investigate the type of carbon deposited on the spent catalysts (Fig. S2). All spent catalysts showed two bands at ∼1300cm−1 (D band) and 1584cm−1 (G band). Appearance of first band indicates disordered sp2-hybridised carbon atoms, while the band at 1584cm−1 signifies E 2g vibration mode of graphite. The relative intensity ratios of the D and G bands (I D/I G) of the spent catalysts can be used to estimate the graphitisation of carbon nanotubes or the degree of disorder in the structure. As shown in Table 3, the estimated I D/I G ratios for Er-, Sm-, and Tm-promoted catalysts were less than 1, while the I D/I G ratios were found to be higher than 1 for the remaining catalysts. These results indicate that the deposited carbon on the Er-, Tm-, and Sm-promoted catalysts was highly graphitised, in good agreement with the TEM results (Fig. 10). Fig. 11(A) shows the correlation of I D/I G ratio to Ni0 particle sizes for promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Several studies have shown that the size of nickel particles in Ni-based catalysts exhibits a significant effect towards formation of carbon filaments or nanotubes [1,23,27,60,62–64]. It was obvious from Fig. 11(A) that the ratio of I D/I G decreases with the decrease of Ni0 particle size and reached a minimum value for the particle size of 18nm (Er-promoted catalyst). Similar results have also been reported in literature [1,13,65–67]. It is therefore concluded that the Ni0 particle size significantly influences the quality of the carbon deposited on the catalyst surface. On the other hand, a linear correlation was found between percentage deactivation behaviour (POD %) with I D/I G ratio of the spent catalysts (Fig. 11(B)). The results showed that while the initial activity of the catalyst was affected by the catalyst reducibility and morphology, the catalyst stability was related to the type of carbon species deposited on the surface of the catalysts, which is dependent to the Ni0 particle size. It can be concluded that the high catalytic performance of Er-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is mainly due to its high reducible nature, low amount of amorphous carbon deposited and optimum Ni particle size. It is therefore strongly believed that these interesting findings will bring new opportunities in the design of novel promising catalysts for the dry reforming of methane. 4 Conclusions In summary, we developed a large number of lanthanide promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts by means of sol–gel method and their catalytic efficiency was studied for dry reforming of methane. It was found that the addition of lanthanides to Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst remarkably improves BET surface area and reducible nature. Surprisingly, initial conversions of CO2 and CH4 are quite low for promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts compared with the un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. This unusual observation is probably due to the smaller pore sizes present in promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. It was found that the type of carbon deposited on the catalysts shows a great effect on the stability of the catalysts in dry reforming of methane. Interestingly, promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited excellent efficiency in time-on-stream studies up to 60h compared with un-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Among all investigated lanthanides, the Er-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest efficacy in DRM reaction, which is attributed to the low amount of amorphous carbon deposited, superior reducible nature, and optimum Ni particle size. coredata.dc:description: The present work was undertaken to investigate the effect of different lanthanide promoters on the structure–activity properties of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for CO2 reforming of CH4. Accordingly, a number of lanthanides, namely Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, and Tm were incorporated into the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by means of sol–gel method. An extensive physicochemical characterisation was performed using XRD, TG-DTA, BET surface area, BJH, XPS, Raman, H2-TPR, and TEM techniques. Surprisingly, low initial conversions of CH4 and CO2 were obtained for promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts compared with un-promoted catalyst, which is due to the presence of smaller pore sizes in the promoted catalysts. The observed initial activity order for conversions of CH4 and CO2 is un-promoted >Eu>Tb>Ho>Tm>Er>Dy>Pr>Sm>Gd>Nd. Interestingly, promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited an outstanding efficiency in time-on-stream studies up to 60h than the un-promoted catalyst. This significant observation is mainly due to low amounts of amorphous coke deposited on the surface of promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts compared with un-promoted catalyst. Among all investigated lanthanides, the Er-promoted Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed the best performance in CH4 conversion, which is attributed to optimum Ni particle size, more reducibility, and low amounts of amorphous coke formation. It was shown that the catalytic efficacy of Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts is highly dependent on the nature of the promoter. These notable findings are expected to bring new opportunities in the design of novel promising catalytic materials for CO2 reforming of CH4.
coredata.dc:title: Understanding the role of lanthanide promoters on the structure–activity of nanosized Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalysts in carbon dioxide reforming of methane
